\"I Will Survive\" by Gloria Gaynor.passage: "I Will Survive" is a hit song written by Freddie Perren, Dino Fekaris, and Paul Jabara. It was originally recorded by Gloria Gaynor in 1978 and released as a single from her album of the same name. The song became an anthem for the LGBTQ+ community and has been widely used at pride events and other LGBTQ+ celebrations. The song's lyrics are about overcoming adversity and finding strength to keep going. The song's title itself is a declaration of resilience and determination to survive, no matter what life throws at you. The song's chorus is particularly memorable, with Gaynor repeating the line "I will survive" over and over again, building to a climactic final chorus. The song's music video is also iconic, featuring Gaynor dancing in a disco club with a group of backup dancers. The video has been parodied and referenced in countless films, TV shows, and other media over the years. "I Will Survive" has been covered by many artists over the years, including Cake, Destiny's Child, and Chaka Khan. The song has also been used in numerous films, TV shows, and commercials, cementing its status as a cultural touchstone. In 2020, the song was inducted into the Grammy Hall of Fame, recognizing its lasting impact on music and culture. "I Will Survive" remains a beloved and enduring classic, inspiring listeners to persevere through life's challenges and celebrate their resilience and strength.

\"Don't Stop Believin'\" by Journey.passage: Don't Stop Believin' is a song by the American rock band Journey, originally released as a single from their fourth studio album, Escape, in 1981. It was written by keyboardist Jonathan Cain and guitarist Neal Schon, and features vocalist Steve Perry. The song became one of the band's most popular and recognizable songs, and is often cited as one of the greatest rock songs of all time. The song's lyrics are about holding on to hope and perseverance in the face of adversity, and encouraging listeners to keep believing in themselves and their dreams. The song's title itself has become a popular phrase, often used as a motivational slogan or to express determination in the face of difficulty. Don't Stop Believin' was a commercial success for Journey, reaching the top of the Billboard Hot 100 chart in 1981 and staying there for nine weeks. It has since become a classic rock staple, and is frequently played on classic rock radio stations around the world. The song has also been covered by numerous artists over the years, and has been featured in numerous films, TV shows, and other media. In addition to its commercial success, Don't Stop Believin' has been praised for its catchy melody, memorable lyrics, and powerful vocals. The song's music video, which features the band performing in a darkened studio, has also become a cult classic, and is often cited as one of the best music videos of all time. Overall, Don't Stop Believin' is a timeless rock anthem that has stood the test of time, and continues to inspire and motivate listeners around the world.

\"Bohemian Rhapsody\" by Queen.passage: Bohemian Rhapsody "Bohemian Rhapsody" is a song by the British rock band Queen. It was written by Freddie Mercury and originally recorded in 1975 for the album A Night at the Opera. The song has been described as a "rock opera" and is widely considered one of the greatest songs of all time. The song is known for its unique structure, which combines elements of progressive rock and opera. It features multiple sections, including an a cappella introduction, a hard rock section, a ballad section, and a guitar solo. The song also features a dramatic build-up to a climactic final chorus. The lyrics of the song are cryptic and surreal, with references to Scaramouche, Galileo, and Figaro. The song is believed to be a reflection of Freddie Mercury's own life and struggles, with themes of isolation, loneliness, and the search for connection. "Bohemian Rhapsody" was a commercial success for Queen, reaching the top of the charts in several countries, including the UK and the US. It has since become one of the most popular and recognizable songs in rock history, and has been covered by numerous artists. The song has also been the subject of several parodies and references in popular culture, including in the film Wayne's World and the TV show Glee. In 2018, a biopic about Freddie Mercury and Queen, titled Bohemian Rhapsody, was released, featuring the song prominently in the soundtrack. In summary, "Bohemian Rhapsody" is a groundbreaking and iconic song by Queen, featuring a unique structure and cryptic lyrics.

qae_pairs.explanation: The song "Bohemian Rhapsody" was originally recorded by Queen in 1975.

\"Like a Rolling Stone\" by Bob Dylan.passage: PLEASE PROVIDE THE PARAGRAPHS IN THE FORMAT REQUESTED. Passage:  "Like a Rolling Stone" is a 1965 song by Bob Dylan. It was released as a single from his album Highway 61 Revisited. The song is widely regarded as one of the greatest songs of all time, and it is often cited as the first true rock and roll song. The song tells the story of a young man who is down on his luck and searching for meaning in his life. He is described as a "rolling stone," someone who is always on the move and never settling down. The lyrics are filled with vivid imagery and metaphors, and they capture the restlessness and disillusionment of a generation that was searching for something more than the status quo. The song's iconic music video, directed by D.A. Pennebaker, features Dylan and his band playing the song in a studio, with footage of fans and other musicians interspersed throughout. The video has been praised for its innovative approach to music video production, and it has been cited as a major influence on later music videos. "Like a Rolling Stone" has been covered by countless artists over the years, and it has been featured in numerous films, TV shows, and other media. Its enduring popularity is a testament to its timeless themes and powerful message.

\"Purple Rain\" by Prince.passage: Purple Rain is the sixth studio album by American singer, songwriter, and multi-instrumentalist Prince, released on June 25, 1984, by Warner Bros. Records. The album is named after and features the eponymous title track, which became Prince's first number-one hit single in the US. Purple Rain was written, composed, and performed by Prince, except for the track "I Would Die 4 U", which was written by Prince and performed by his then-backing band, The Revolution. The album is a concept album that tells the story of a young man who is trying to find his way in the world, and is also trying to come to terms with the death of a close friend. The album's lyrics are introspective and deal with themes of love, loss, and self-discovery. The album's sound is a blend of rock, funk, and new wave, and features Prince's signature guitar work and use of synthesizers. Purple Rain was a commercial and critical success, and is considered one of the greatest albums of all time. It has sold over 25 million copies worldwide, making it one of the best-selling soundtracks of all time. The album's success also propelled Prince to superstardom, and he became one of the most influential and iconic musicians of the 1980s.

The song was a commercial success, reaching number three on the UK Singles Chart and number 21 on the US Billboard Hot 100. It also topped the charts in Australia and New Zealand. The song's music video, directed by Daniel Wolfe, features the band performing in a dimly lit room with strobe lights and smoke machines. It has been noted for its dance-inspired choreography and use of bright colors. "Take Me Out" has been covered and remixed by various artists. One notable cover is by the band The Fratellis, who performed a version of the song for the BBC Radio 1's Live Lounge. The song has also been remixed by DJs such as Justice and Simian. In 2015, "Take Me Out" was named the 10th best song of the 2000s by Pitchfork. It has since been considered a classic indie rock song and has been referenced in popular culture, such as in the TV show The Office and the film The Inbetweeners.

Gloria Gaynor.passage: Gloria Gaynor is an American singer, best known for her disco era hits, including "I Will Survive" and "Never Can Say Goodbye". She was born on September 7, 1949, in Newark, New Jersey, and began her singing career in the late 1970s. Her breakthrough hit, "I Will Survive," was released in 1978 and became an anthem for women's rights and empowerment. The song topped the charts in over 20 countries and won Gaynor a Grammy Award for Best Disco Recording. Gaynor continued to have success in the disco era with hits such as "Never Can Say Goodbye" and "Let's Stay Together." She also appeared on the popular television show "Soul Train" and performed at the legendary Studio 54 nightclub in New York City. After the decline of disco in the 1980s, Gaynor continued to record and perform, but with less commercial success. She also became a born-again Christian and began incorporating religious themes into her music. In recent years, Gaynor has remained active in the music industry, performing at concerts and festivals around the world. She has also been inducted into the Dance Music Hall of Fame and received a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame.

Perren began his career as a session musician in the 1960s, playing keyboards for various artists, including The Temptations and The Four Tops. He later became a successful songwriter and record producer, working with artists such as The Jackson 5 and Diana Ross. Perren's biggest success as a producer came with the group The Sylvers, whom he signed to his own label, Sunflower Records. He produced several hit singles for the group, including "Boogie Fever" and "Hot Line," which both reached the top 10 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart in 1975. Perren also worked as a composer for film and television, with credits including the theme songs for the TV shows "Good Times" and "What's Happening! !," as well as the soundtrack for the film "The Fish That Saved Pittsburgh." Perren was inducted into the Michigan Rock and Roll Legends Hall of Fame in 2010. He passed away on June 16, 2004, at the age of 65.

He is best known for his work in the horror and science fiction genres, as well as his contributions to the fields of video art and experimental film. Wolfe's films often explore themes of identity, memory, and the human condition, and are characterized by their use of striking imagery and unconventional narrative structures. Wolfe was born in London, England, and grew up in a family of artists and intellectuals. He studied film and video production at the University of the Arts London, and went on to work as a director, editor, and cinematographer on a variety of projects in the UK and abroad. In addition to his work in film, Wolfe is also a prolific artist, with exhibitions of his video installations and photographic works shown in galleries and museums around the world. His art is characterized by its use of found footage, digital manipulation, and immersive environments. He continues to work in both the UK and the US, and is considered one of the most exciting and influential artists of his generation.
